I have an immense love/hate relationship with this game. While on one hand this game is insanely fun (usually) and addicting, it can also be an absolute nightmare. 

Now, let's start off with the positives:
(PS I may only have 32 hours on Steam at the time I'm writing this, but I have at least 1,000 on PS4 so I'm not a baby who barely understands what I'm saying.)

First things first, I'm a huge fan of the overall world of Dead by Daylight, with the lore of characters such as The Oni and The Blight being incredibly immersive and interesting (Blight especially since I find Britain during the First Opium War to be incredibly interesting). 
Second, I'm a big fan of the creativity of the team, although their creativity often bites them in the ass in the long run, case in point, The Twins. While The Twins are some of the most creative killers to date, their power isn't exactly the best, and as of the time I'm writing (2 Days after they launched), they don't even work.
Finally, I can respect how our lads at BHVR are pretty dedicated to their game, even though they aren't exactly the best at managing it, we'll get into that later.

That isn't anywhere near every little bit of praise I have for this game, but I don't exactly think I can write them all down.

Now, we move onto the issues I have with this game, which, unfortunately, I have more to talk about than with the things I enjoy.

I'll start with easily the biggest issue I have with the game, and what is pretty much the main reason why I don't recommend it; it is way too hard for a new player to get into. Every 3 months, the game receives a new expansion that includes a killer with a completely new and original power, 6 new perks, and, up until recently, a new map. This is absolutely hell for a new player to learn and understand, with 164 perks, 22 killers and 35 maps, new players are incredibly overwhelmed, and this issue grows worse every 3 months. I was lucky enough to have first gotten the game when The Clown was still a relatively new killer, so I didn't struggle all too much, but I feel sorry for anyone who's just bought the game. I feel like perks such as Decisive Strike and Hex: No One Escapes Death are made more problematic by the fact that new players don't know about them, so when they get DStriked or insta-downed, they'd feel (understandably), cheated out of a win, as it wasn't their fault they didn't know what those perks did.

My next issue is concerning the developers of the game, BHVR, and their poor treatment and understanding of the game. While I really do try my hardest to support and defend these chaps, I still feel like I have to admit that they really do need to improve their behaviour (pun very much intended). For starters, I would like to point out their blatant lack of understanding of how the game works, such as one of the developers saying that Clown is a strong killer, but in his current state as of 2/12/20, he is absolute rubbish and is in dire need of a rework (I know that he's getting one). They're also starting to gain a reputation for making unnecessary changes, while the things that actually do need changes are just ignored, for example, nerfing The Pig and leaving The Spirit the way she is. I hope that this trend does not continue in the future, for I love this game to bits, and I really don't want it to die.

So in conclusion, while I love this game to pieces, I really, really do not recommend that you pick it up unless you're confident that you will like the game and have an understanding of how it works.

Given this game far too much of my time, and in no way does it deserve it. Devs are memeworthy at this point with how many mistakes they make. They are more interested in making a quick $ then focusing on the countless flaws and bugs with their game, and it's honestly embarrassing at this point, and cannot be defended any longer. If you are planning on buying this game, consider if you are okay with a game which has more interest in putting out a new cosmetic every week than fixing the bugs which every update seems to introduce more of. Other reviews will tell you how bad the bugs are, every "patch" introduces more bugs than it fixes, and these bugs break things which should not have problems and have no correlation to anything that's been added. Without fail, at least one perk, if not more, breaks and no longer works properly/at all every update. Licensed DLC killer Freddy has been ruined for a ridiculously long time, with the devs continuously telling us they're working on a revamp of the killer, which has been going on for what feels like at least a year now. Concept of the game is good, but the poor effort from the devs who have their priorities in the wrong places ruin this game, and people considering buying this game deserve to know what they're getting themselves into. To top it all off, it has what could possibly be one of the most toxic gaming communities of all time.

If you like buying cosmetics for a game that doesn't work properly, and then experiencing toxic gameplay/post game chats every other game, this is one for you.

This game can put you through heaven and hell within a timespan of just 10 minutes. Sometimes it is like the bruise on your arm that hurts when you touch it but still you cannot stop touching it over and over again....I think the term "sweet sweet pain" describes it the best. I am usually playing survivor main and I am, by all means, just a very mediocore player. 

In my opinion there are a number of things you need to make yourself aware of before really playing DBD:

1. The game is designed to frustrate you. There will be plenty of situations where your oponent will tunnel you, hook camp you, outsmart you at the mindgames or have a setup which counters yours in every way. It will leave you with an utter sense of frustration, unfairness and game mechanics beeing broken. But just 1 match where you are able to outsmart your oponent or the match is just very exciting because of everybody kind of being at the same level, will get you instantly hooked again.
2. This game is antisocial social..... as survivors you are not able to communicate with each other except by handsigns during the match (if you are not playing with a group of friends). This makes it almost feel as a singleplayer game sometimes adding to the feeling of dread an "being by yourself against a Killer that is faster and stronger than you". Also when playing a Killer you are supposed to be antisocial and free of remorse. Yes, this sometimes mean you will encounter Killers that tunnel and/or camp you. Deal with it and hope your fellow survivors counter this strategy by concentrating on doing gens. 
3. You will encounter a lot, lot, lot very antisocial people. People will disconnect a lot when, for example, they get hit by the Killer or as the Killer they feel like they don't stand a chance against the survivors. I think there should be more punishments for players doing this but on the other hand this sometimes also leads to situations where the "remaining" players really can shine.
4. The game has a very steep learning curve which can add to the frustration.

So, I keep coming back to play this game because it is so rewarding in a frustrating way. Very different from all other games that I have played so far. I will continue to "play to lose"

I really like the idea,setting and the style this game is using but it is not well done.

In fact you can see how the develepers rather push out content then fixing major bugs and ignore really good sugestions done by the community.

I like how this game can be scary and fun but is sometimes just as frustrating because of hitbox issues and ther bugs which make the game unplayable sometimes and often unenjoyable.

Update: July 21 2022: For the first time in the past 3 years it is fun to play both sides. The last update brought a lot of needed changes to the game. The only ones crying are because they can't play with out getting 100 2nd chances. 

Update: MMR 100% fucked the game. Good news is i have finally have a reason to uninstall and move on from this shit show.  

I normally don't write reviews but i had to for this one. The core idea of the game is amazing enough that i can look past all the bugs the game has after each patch.

At the end of the day i still can't recommend the game mainly due to the ranking system. It is something i have had a problem with for a long time, and to tell you the truth i am just sick of it. There is no reason when you are rank 20 -15  you should be playing with people with over 3000+ hours. Most ranking systems are put in place so you can play with people of your own skill level. I think this is a big part of why so many pick up the game and never really stick with it. 

To say its frustrating to have a full lobby of survivors or a killer who have been rank 1 and have 1000s of hours at rank 20 is an understatement. It really hard to learn the game when i get lobbies like this all the time. I really think something needs to be done about this, but seeing as the rank system has not changed in 4 year almost i don't see any changes ever come.

200+ hours in this game and it's still fresh every time. Yes, the learning curve is basically a cliff for your first dozen matches and your fellow survivors can be worse than AI bots, but once you get the core mechanics down and start to learn the tricks of evading the killer or juking a survivor the game shows its true genius.

The devs are continually updating the game, new killers, maps, and survivors keep it fresh. I wish Killers would get notified or some sort of bonus for facing SWF teams but thats really my only complaint about the game. It's an otherwise perfect game in this genre.
